title: Fort Dupont
listingDescription: Fort Dupont was commenced between Ocotober and December of 1861 and "completed" in the spring on 1862. It was named for Flag Officer Samuel F. Dupont, who commanded the naval victory at Port Royal, South Carolina, in November 1861.

images.altText: Several people are gathered around a stage and waiting for a summer concert to begin at Fort Dupont.
images.title: Fort Dupont
images.caption: Summer concerts are annual events at Fort Dupont.

bodyText:
Fort Dupont was erected as part of the Eastern Branch Line Defenses (Anacostia River). Constructiobn commenced between Ocotober and December of 1861, and "completed" in the spring of 1862. The fort was built to protect a critical Ridge
Road (Alabama Avenue) intersection and was supported by Forts Meigs and Chaplin to the north and Fort Davis to the south.

Fort DuPont was a regular hexagonal redoubt, designed for 14 guns, 12
firing through embrasures. Fort Dupont had six sides, each 100 feet long, protected by a deep moat and trees felled side-by-side with branches pointing outward. It was named for Flag Officer Samuel F. Dupont, who commanded the naval victory at Port Royal, South Carolina, in November 1861.

It was never a strong work and in 1862, a commission studying the Defenses of Washington noted that a deep ravine to the west of the fort should be covered by a blockhouse. At other times, traverses to cover the sally port, magazine and rifle pits to the cover approaches were recommended.

In April 1864, Brigadier General John G. Barnard, Chief Engineer, advised the abandonment of Fort Dupont. The army officially abandoned the fort in 1865. The grounds reverted to its original landowner, Michael Caton. 

Although its garrison and guns never saw battle, Fort Dupont served as a lifeline of freedom. Runaway slaves found safety here before moving on to join the growing community of "contrabands" in Washington. The barracks and guns are gone, but the fort's earthworks can still be traced near the picnic area on Alabama Avenue.

In the 1930s, the National Capital Planning Commission acquired the old fort and surrounding land for recreation. A golf course was constructed and as the city grew, golf gave way in 1970 to the sports complex along Ely Place that now includes tennis and basketball courts, athletic fields, a softball diamond, and an indoor ice rink.  Once where soldiers viewed farmlands, park visitors now grow fruits and vegetables in the community garden.
audioDescription:
(513 words)
Fort Dupont is located along the north side of Alabama avenue, SE in Southeast Washington, D.C. The park is bordered by Massachusetts avenue to the west and Burns street to the east.
From the intersection of Alabama avenue and Massachusetts avenue, travel about eight hundred thirty feet. Turn left into the park entrance. A brown sign will be on the right with white letters that read:
Fort Circle Park
Picnic Area
Park Closed at Dark
Proceed to the left along an asphalt-paved path that loops around in a circle in the park, passing through a parking lot. At the north end of the parking lot, the path continues. Proceed about one hundred fifty yards along the path. On your right about ten feet off the path in a grassy knoll at the edge of the forest line is a four by three-foot yellow wayside. Titled across the top in brown letters it reads:
Fort DuPont
Earthworks of Fort Dupont are visible, follow path to the entrance of fort.
Below across a blue border is written in white letters:
Civil War Defenses of Washington
1861-1865
Below to the left is a diagram titled "Fort Dupont." It features a rectangular building surrounded by three hexagonal walls. Text below reads:
Fort DuPont from U.S. Army Corps of Engineers drawing.
Fort DuPont was named after Rear Admiral Samuel Francis DuPont, a Union naval hero of the early years of the Civil War.
To the right is a map of Washington and the edge of Virginia at the bottom. The map indicates Civil War fort locations along this section of Washington. They are, from left to right Fort Marcy, Battery Kemble, Fort Bayard, Fort Reno, Fort De Russy, Fort Stevenson, Fort Slocum, Fort Totten, Fort Bunker Hill, Fort Mahan, Fort Chaplin, Fort Dupont, Fort Davis, Fort Stanton, Battery Rickets, Fort Carrol, and Fort Greble.
Text below reads: "Other Civil War fort locations administered by the National Park Service.
The bottom third of the sign shows a black and white photograph of Civil War soldiers standing in a fort around an eight-foot long cannon on a rotating platform, aimed to the left. The fort sits atop a tall hill with a vast view in the background of open spaces and rolling hills.
The caption below reads:
During the Civil War, Washington's forts overlooked the land.
About forty feet to the left of the wayside, also set along the tree line, is a four-foot-tall, four-foot-wide, and two-foot-tall rock with a bronze plaque set on its face. The plaque is about one by two feet, and engraved to read:
The Civil War Defenses of Washington
Fort DuPont
This small work was one of the defenses begun in Fall of 1861 on the ridge east of the Anacostia River. It was named after Admiral Samuel F. DuPont, a commander of the South Atlantic Blockage Squadron. Eight guns and one mortar comprised its armament.
United States Department of the Interior
National Park Service, National Capital Parks
Presented by the National Society of the Colonial Dames of America
In the District of Columbia
1955
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Fort Dupont Community Gardens
listingDescription: One of the largest community gardens in Washington, DC, the Fort Dupont Community Gardens increases the accessibility and exposure of fruits and vegetables as well as providing education on nutrition and sustainable agriculture for urban residents. The Community Gardens of Fort DuPont provide education through shared knowledge and agricultural practices by empowering the community to grow its own healthy food.
bodyText: One of the largest community gardens in Washington, DC, the Fort Dupont Community Gardens increases the accessibility and exposure of fruits and vegetables as well as providing education on nutrition and sustainable agriculture for urban residents. The Community Gardens of Fort DuPont provide education through shared knowledge and agricultural practices by empowering the community to grow its own healthy food.

title: Fort Dupont Historic Earthwork picnic area
listingDescription:
Picnic amid history at the site of Fort Dupont's historic earthworks.

Picnickers may reserve sites through Recreation.gov .

images.altText: Two picnic tables in front of a large red building.
images.title: Historic Earthwork picnic area
images.caption: Fort Dupont Historic Earthwork picnic area

bodyText:
Picnic amidst history at the site of Fort Dupont's historic earthworks.

Picnickers may reserve sites through Recreation.gov .

title: Fort Dupont Randle Circle picnic area
listingDescription:
The picnic grove at Fort Dupont offers a number of recreational opportunities. In addition to picnicking, visitors can hike the nearby trails that link the various Civil War-era forts that protected the capital.

Picnickers may reserve sites through Recreation.gov .

images.altText: Picnic benches in a grassy field.
images.title: Randle Circle picnic area
images.caption: Fort Dupont Randle Circle picnic area

bodyText:

title: Fort Dupont Summer Theater
listingDescription: Since the late 1960s, the Fort Dupont theater has been a popular venue for outdoor concerts in the summer.

images.altText: Several people are gathered around the Fort Dupont Summer Theatre stage for an evening summer concer
images.title: Fort Dupont Summer Theater
images.caption: Summer concerts are annual events at Fort Dupont.

bodyText: Since the late 1960s, the Fort Dupont theater has been a popular venue for outdoor concerts in the summer.

title: Fort Foote Park
listingDescription: Fort Foote was constructed in 1863 atop Rozier's Bluff to strengthen the ring of fortifications that encircled Washington, DC. Two of the Guns that protected Washington are still there along with the remains of the fort's earthworks.

images.altText: A large 15-inch Rodman Cannon stands among several trees at Fort Foote.
images.title: A 15-inch Rodman Cannon at Fort Foote.
images.caption: A 15-inch Rodman Cannon at Fort Foote.

bodyText: Fort Foote was constructed in 1863 atop Rozier's Bluff to strengthen the ring of fortifications that encircled Washington, DC. Two of the Guns that protected Washington are still there along with the remains of the fort's earthworks.

title: Information Panel: Animal Homes
listingDescription: The forest provides a home for many types of animals. While walking on the trail look closely for these homes nests made of materials such as grasses, twigs or leaves, holes in the ground, in trees, or fallen logs.

images.altText: An information panel with scratches displays a tree trunk with a fox laying at its bottom.
images.title: Information Panel: Animal Homes
images.caption: Information Panel: Animal Homes

bodyText: The forest provides a home for many types of animals. While walking on the trail look closely for these homes nests made of materials such as grasses, twigs or leaves, holes in the ground, in trees, or fallen logs. During the summer months many of these homes are hidden by leaves, but in winter, animal homes are easier to see. How many can you find?
audioDescription: A small information panel sits low to the ground surrounded by green leaves and branches. A tree trunk sits to the back right of the panel.

title: Information Panel: Basement Dwellers
listingDescription: This log is a home and feeding ground for many insects and small animals such as termites, bark beetles, and carpenter ants.

images.altText: A spotted salamander is pictured near green leaves on an information panel.
images.title: Information Panel: Basement Dwellers
images.caption: Information Panel: Basement Dwellers

bodyText: This log is a home and feeding ground for many insects and small animals such as termites, bark beetles, and carpenter ants. Look closely to see some of the tunnels these insects have made throughout the log. Earthworms, salamanders, and moles also use logs as homes, preferring the moist underside as a place to live and feed. Please do not disturb the log or harm any of the creatures living here.
audioDescription: A small information panel sits low to the ground, seemingly encompassed by many green leaves, as if the panel is coming out of the leaves. Thick tree roots are seen in the background to the right.

title: Information Panel: Giants of the Forest
listingDescription: Trees dominate the forest. By controlling the amount of sunlight that reaches the forest floor, they influence all woodland plants and animals.

images.altText: A chestnut oak and it's leaves are displayed on a sign low to the ground.
images.title: Information Panel: Giants of the Forest
images.caption: Information Panel: Giants of the Forest

bodyText: Trees dominate the forest. By controlling the amount of sunlight that reaches the forest floor, they influence all woodland plants and animals. Some of the tallest and oldest trees in the park are chestnut oak which you see here. Like all oak trees in the park, this tree produces acorns in the fall which are eaten by squirrels and deer. You can identify the chestnut oak by its sawtooth edged leaves in summer and its deeply ridged bark in winter.
audioDescription: A small information panel sits low to the ground surrounded by leaves and green plants.

title: Information Panel: Preserving A Community
listingDescription: Each plant and creature occupies a special place within it the forest community and plays a vital role in keeping it in balance.

images.altText: A sign is positioned low to the ground and has an image of many animals roaming in a habitat.
images.title: Info Panel: Preserving A Community
images.caption: Information Panel: Preserving A Community

bodyText: Each plant and creature occupies a special place within it the forest community and plays a vital role in keeping it in balance. The more places within a community the more diverse it is. To preserve the natural woodland of Fort Dupont Park, we must protect even the smallest life so the forest maintains its diversity.
audioDescription: A sign is positioned low to the ground. It's surrounded by plants, leaves, and branches on the ground.

title: InformationPanel: Two Types of Trees
listingDescription: There are two basic kinds of trees: evergreens, like spruces or pines, and deciduous, like oaks or maples.

images.altText: White pine and red oak trees and leaves are displayed on a small information panel.
images.title: Information Panel: Two Types of Trees
images.caption: Information Panel: Two Types of Trees

bodyText: There are two basic kinds of trees: evergreens, like spruces or pines, and deciduous, like oaks or maples. Evergreen trees usually have needle-like leaves with small surface areas, while deciduous trees have flat leaves with large surface areas. Since trees allow moisture to escape through their leaves, deciduous trees drop their leaves in the fall to avoid the cold, dry winter months. Evergreen trees can keep their needles year-round, continuously shedding and growing new ones.
audioDescription: A small information panel sits low to the ground surrounded by green leaves and dirt.
